title: Calculator

parsed_exercises.title: Introduction
parsed_exercises.description: This is a very simple calculator that can only do additions with 2 arguments. Pressing the button Run code (play) you can see the HTML page. Pressing the title Calculator or the selector you can access the different exercises of this selfevaluation test. Pressing the button Run Code, test the calculator and go to the first exercise.
parsed_exercises.content: Number:

parsed_exercises.title: a) HTML tags
parsed_exercises.description:
Add a header to the HTML document (with the
tag) with identifier "myheader", class "big", an attribute "title" with value "Main header" and content "Welcome to my calculator"
parsed_exercises.content: Number:

parsed_exercises.title: b)  CSS styles
parsed_exercises.description: Complete and modify the content of the
parsed_exercises.content: Number:

parsed_exercises.title: c)  Error management
parsed_exercises.description: Modify the calculator so that when any of the arguments introduced are a text instead of a number, it shows in the screen the message 'Error'.
parsed_exercises.content: Number:

parsed_exercises.title: d) Multiply
parsed_exercises.description: Add a new button to the calculator with identifier "multiplication" and text "x" that performs multiplications with two arguments.
parsed_exercises.content: Number:

parsed_exercises.title: e) Function f(b,x)
parsed_exercises.description: Add a new button to the calculator with an "fbx" identifier and text "f(b,x)" that implements the following mathematical operation: f(b,x) = logb(x) = log10(x)/log10(b) . Where logb(x) is the logarithm in base b of x, and the variables b and x are, respectively, the first and second operand entered in the calculator. The function must display the "Error" message on the screen if b is not a natural number greater than 1 or if x is not a real positive number. Thus, when performing the following interaction (2)[f(b,x)](8) the final result displayed by the screen should be 3. NOTE: You can use the JavaScript Math.log10 function to calculate logarithms on the basis of 10. >.
parsed_exercises.content: Number:

parsed_exercises.title: f) Error counter
parsed_exercises.description:

with a "counter" identifier that shows the number of errors in the calculator. The counter will start with the value 0 and increase by 1 each time an error is displayed on the calculator display. 2) Make use of the error class defined in the
